Federal tax statutes, technical issues and social problems involved in tax planning, tax litigation, and reform of the tax laws.

Open to incoming LL.M. students only.
The protection of intellectual property and encouragement of creativity. Explores copyright, trademarks, patents, and selected state law theories.

An examination of how the courts are handling selected, "cutting edge" topics in entertainment law. Previous entertainment law courses recommended, but not required.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An overview of common legal issues impacting both providers and users of Internet services.

Design and implementation of marketing strategies applied to domestic and global business challenges that span multiple industries complimented by a consumer packaged goods marketing strategic plan project.

COURSE_TITLE: Marketing Models in Consumer and Business-to-Business Markets
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Modeling research on marketing with a focus on channel structure, franchising and sales force compensation, innovation and diffusion, inter-store competition, sales promotions, and market segmentation.  Open to students in the doctoral program in business administration only.
Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Marketing. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open to Marshall Ph.D. students only. Graded CR/NC.
Exploration of emerging topics, literature and research techniques in contemporary marketing.
SECTION_NAME: Unstructured Data and the Pursuit of Replicable Research

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Survey of strategic management. Topics include historical overview of strategic management, research methods used, current theory, and empirical research on the developing paradigms. Open only to Business Administration doctoral students.
How to develop strategy approaches for managing new technology in business with a focus on artificial intelligence.

Role of professional consultants; data gathering methods; consulting approaches from strategy, finance, operations, information systems, marketing, and human resources; action planning; ethical and career issues.

COURSE_TITLE: The Art of Leadership - Self Discovery
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introductory leadership. Self-examination of personal leadership styles using survey tools, comparative models and in-class exercises. Duplicates credit in former MOR 476a. Open only to students in the USC Warren Bennis Scholars Program.

Theories, strategies, and ethics underlying negotiation and persuasion in contemporary organizations and societies. Emphasizes the knowledge and skills needed for effective negotiation and persuasion.

Theories, strategies, and ethics underlying negotiation and persuasion in contemporary organizations and societies. Emphasizes the knowledge and skills needed for effective negotiation and persuasion.

Major theories and practices of leading people in multi-national firms.  Skills for facilitating cooperation, communication, and motivation among people from different cultures. Recommended preparation: BUAD 304
Theories and practices about how power, politics and influence affect organizational life.  Knowledge and skills for diagnosing and managing these features of an organization.
Cross-cultural awareness, knowledge, and skills necessary to negotiate effectively with counterparts from other cultures and countries.
Examination of corporate strategy practices in an international context.  Effects of cultures, political systems, markets, and economic systems on developing effective global strategies.

COURSE_TITLE: Social and Ethical Issues in Business
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Explores ethical issues in business from diverse perspectives including the roles and responsibilities of institutional actors, corporate social responsibility and balancing stakeholder interest.
Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory. (Graded CR/NC)

COURSE_TITLE: Sports Business Innovation: Impacts on Decision Making
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Investigates how innovation in sports business influences industry cash flow and executive decision making. Examines emerging areas of innovation and their impacts on industry stakeholders.
Management of the human resource function for organizational performance.  Recommended preparation: BUAD 304.

Globalization strategies from entry to maturity; alternative approaches from going alone to alliances; strategy implementation issues in different cultures and political systems. Cases, videos and speakers.
Development of skills and insight into making effective strategic, financial, and management decisions including awareness of hazards of decisions, issues of rationality, and risk taking.

How consultants assist clients to formulate strategic plans and realign organizations; approaches used by major consulting firms; information about consulting industry, fee-setting and proposals. Consultant speakers and project.

Dynamic strategic planning; how businesses re-invent themselves; why change is difficult; politics of change process; leadership steps for implementing successful strategic changes. Cases and readings.
Theory and practice of organization design. How to maximize organization performance by aligning structure, rewards, staffing, processes, and culture with strategy and environment.
Practical knowledge on helping organizations develop innovations and lead change to leverage them. Exploration of innovation and change in different organizations and competitive environments.

Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in a range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.
Advanced strategic planning using tools of scenario development and activity valuation for assessing market entry, expansion and business portfolio configuration. Exercises, cases and project.

Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in a range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.

Contemporary approaches to leadership, including corporate practices to develop leaders; examples of successful and derailed executives. Students self-assess personal leadership and draft development plans. Readings, speakers, cases.

Business practices and issues in different sports markets including growth opportunities and innovative marketing strategies for attracting and retaining fans and corporate sponsors. Industry speakers.

Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in a range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.
Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

COURSE_TITLE: Independent Research in Management and Organization
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.
Legitimate and effective use of power to resolve conflicts and mobilize action through understanding the talent and self-interest of people involved in decision-making. Readings, cases.

COURSE_TITLE: Consulting Project in Management and Organization
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.
Legitimate and effective use of power to resolve conflicts and mobilize action through understanding the talent and self-interest of people involved in decision-making. Readings, cases.
Central challenges facing executives in multi-business firms; toolkit for analyzing and executing strategic and operational aspects of corporate advantage, M&As; and competitive dynamics.
Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.
SECTION_NAME: Power, Players and Platforms in Global Sports

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Addresses the business side of the sports industry; examines professional sports franchises, amateur athletics, and collegiate sports and how they relate to corporate America, the media, and the public sector. Recommended Preparation BUAD 304.
Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in management and policy sciences.

COURSE_TITLE: Field Research in Management and Organization
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Individual or team projects studying the management practices of an industry, company, government agency, country geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

COURSE_TITLE: Independent Research in Management and Organization
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.
Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.)

COURSE_TITLE: Research Practicum in Management and Organization
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Management and Organization Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC.

COURSE_TITLE: Leading and Coaching: Foundations and Practicum
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Marshall MBA Leadership Fellows Program (MLFP). Learn, practice and teach leadership. Engage in critical thinking and problem solving. (a) Foundations. (b) Practicum. Application required.
In-depth review of the theories and empirical research in the discipline of organizational behavior. Topics include: personality, motivation, job design, leadership, and others.
Research leading to the doctorate. Open only to Marshall Ph.D. students specializing in Management and Organization. Graded CR/NC.

Understand the concept of risk, risk assessment, and management frameworks. Learn to identify, analyze, manage and mitigate, and communicate this risk to stakeholders. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 380.

Understand the concept of risk, risk assessment, and management frameworks. Learn to identify, analyze, manage and mitigate, and communicate this risk to stakeholders. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 380.

COURSE_TITLE: Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Understand the underlying economics, structure, and business models of an organization (often an insurance carrier) willing to accept risk for diverse situations: property, life, healthcare. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 385.

COURSE_TITLE: Risk Management in Entertainment, Sports and the Arts
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Knowledge and skills needed to identify, analyze, control, finance and report on the risks particular to entertainment, sports and the arts. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 387.
The practical application of enterprise risk management across a broad spectrum of business settings and industry types, from start-up to multinational organizations.

COURSE_TITLE: Foundations of Library and Information Science
INSTRUCTOR_NAME: Wallach, Ruth;Chen, Michael;Lee, Jenny;Montante, Christopher;Perez, Nicolas
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: History and evolution of libraries and information organizations, including their structure, funding, role in society, and impact on the communities they serve.

INSTRUCTOR_NAME: Ullmann, Michaela;Chen, Michael;Lee, Jenny;Montante, Christopher;Perez, Nicolas
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: History and evolution of libraries and information organizations, including their structure, funding, role in society, and impact on the communities they serve.
Developments in reference and user services, including tools and processes for ethical information evaluation, retrieval and delivery for users in diverse library settings.
Developments in reference and user services, including tools and processes for ethical information evaluation, retrieval and delivery for users in diverse library settings.

INSTRUCTOR_NAME: Miller, Melissa;Chen, Michael;Lee, Jenny;Montante, Christopher;Perez, Nicolas
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Effective application of interdisciplinary, community-centered leadership concepts in libraries and information organizations, with a focus on mission-driven, inclusive strategic planning and change management.
Searching sophisticated for-fee and free sources of information unique to particular industry client groups, synthesizing and translating information ethically to critical intelligence.

COURSE_TITLE: Information Organization and Description for User Engagement
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Theories, standards, and tools for the organization and description of information with the goal of equitable and inclusive access for users.

COURSE_TITLE: Independent Research in Library and Information Management
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Opportunity to pursue independent research in an area of interest above and beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required.

COURSE_TITLE: Capstone in Library and Information Management
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Knowledge and skills gained throughout the MMLIS program are synthesized in a culminating capstone project, and deployed in service of career advancement.

An introduction to basic Tap Dance technique, rhythms, syncopation, and musicality, developing into complex steps and elementary dances with progressive understanding of weight change, improvisation, and combinations of sound.
Explore the movement language, rooted in guided improvisation, developed by Ohad Naharin of Batsheva Dance Company. Open to all, regardless of dance or movement background.

COURSE_TITLE: Colloquium II: Investing in the Collaboratory
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Continued investment in the creative community, with a focus on best practices for sharing work, soliciting feedback and establishing healthy relationships with fellow creators.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Intermediate technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development.

Examination of the role of dance in popular culture in a classroom setting. Studies of dance styles and their evolution in recreational and professional contexts through research, observation, and practice.

INSTRUCTOR_NAME: Struxness, Betsy;Grayson, Shannon, Johnson;Kingsberry, Grasan;Kopcsak, Jackie
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Continued studies and guided practice of choreographic repertory. Investigation of choreographic vocabulary, intention, stylistic approaches, and performance technique for group work.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Continued studies and guided practice of choreographic repertory. Investigation of choreographic vocabulary, intention, stylistic approaches, and performance technique for group work.
An introduction to collaborative creation across disciplinary boundaries, working toward the integration of varied design elements into choreographic composition.

COURSE_TITLE: Introduction to Dance as an Art Form
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Gateway to the minor in dance.  An interdisciplinary overview of dance relating to the aesthetic and art in various subjects. Applications of the elements of dance studies, art criticism, and viewing productions to explore topic such as architecture, photography, poetry, technology, cinematic arts, sports, medicine, and more.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An intermediate/advanced-level survey of music copyright law, artist contract analysis, infringement case studies as they affect modern/emerging business models and global music licensing.

An exploration of the most current and effective marketing strategies and online branding tools for promoting, monetizing, and sustaining the career of the independent creative artist. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.
